Chapter 2. Regression

 

2.1 Weight-space View

Let D={(xn,yn)∣n=1,…,N} be a training set of N observations.

  • xn∈RD denotes an input vector (covariates)

  • yn∈R denotes a scalar output or target (dependent variable)

We can write D=(X,y) where

  • X is the N×D design matrix with row vectors xn∈RD

  • y=(y1,y2,…,yN)∈RN is the target vector

 

2.1.1 The Standard Linear Model

Reference: Probabilistic Machine Learning: An Introduction, 11.7 Bayesian linear regression (p.399)

The Bayesian analysis of the standard linear regression model with Gaussian noise:

f(x)=xTw,y=f(x)+ϵ,ϵ∼N(0,σn2)

  • Likelihood: The probability density of the observations given the parameters, which is factored over cases in the training set,

p(y|X,w)=∏n=1Np(yn|xn,w)=N(y|Xw,σn2I).

  • Prior: Our beliefs about the parameters before we look at the observations,

    p(w)=N(w|0,Σp).

  • Posterior: Inference in the Bayesian linear model is based on the posterior distribution over the weights,

    (2.5)posterior=likelihood×priormarginal likelihood,p(w|y,X)=p(y|X,w)p(w)p(y|X),

    where the marginal likelihood is independent of the weights and given by

    p(y|X)=∫p(y|X,w)p(w)dw.

 

The posterior in (2.5) combines the likelihood and the prior, and captures everything we know about the parameters. Writing only the terms from the likelihood and prior which depend on the weights, we obtain

p(w|X,y)∝exp⁡[−12σn2(y−Xw)T(y−Xw)]⋅exp⁡[−12wTΣp−1w]∝exp⁡[−12(wTAw−2wTAw¯)]∝exp⁡[−12(w−w¯)TA(w−w¯)]

where w¯=1σn2A−1XTy and A=1σn2XTX+Σp−1. Thus the posterior has the form of Gaussian with mean w¯ and covariance matrix A−1,

p(w|X,y)=N(w|w¯,A−1).

  • For any Gaussian posterior, the mean w¯ is also its mode, which is called the maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimate.

  • In a non-Bayesian setting the negative log prior 12wTΣp−1w is sometimes thought of as a (L2) penalty term (regularization), and the MAP point is known as the penalized maximum likelihood estimate of the weights.

  • However, in the Bayesian setting the MAP estimate plays no special role.

  • The (L2) penalized maximum likelihood procedure is known (in this case) as ridge regression because of the effect of the quadratic penalty term 12wTΣp−1w from the negative log prior.

 

The posterior predictive distribution for (noiseless) function value f∗≡f(x∗)=x∗Tw is

(2.9)p(f∗|x∗,X,y)=N(f∗|E[f∗],V[f∗])=N(f∗|x∗Tw¯,x∗TA−1x∗),

since w∼p(w|X,y)=N(w|w¯,A−1).

 

The posterior predictive distribution for noise observation y∗=f(x∗)+ϵ is

p(y∗|x∗,X,y)=∫p(y∗|x∗,w)p(w|X,y)dw=N(y∗|x∗Tw¯,x∗TA−1x∗+σn2).

Reference: Probabilistic Machine Learning: An Introduction, 3.3.1 Bayes rule for Gaussians (p.85, eq. 3.38)

 

2.1.2 Projections of Inputs into Feature Space

Let ϕ:RD→RD¯ be a function which maps an input vector x∈RD into a D¯ dimensional feature space, and let Φ(X) be the aggregation (N×D¯ matrix) of rows ϕ(xn)∈RD¯ for all cases in the training set.

Now the model is f(x)=ϕ(x)Tw for some parameter w∈RD¯.

  • The analysis for this model is analogous to the standard linear model, except that everywhere Φ(X) is substituted for X.

  • The posterior predictive distribution (2.9) becomes

    (2.11)p(f∗|x∗,X,y)=N(f∗|ϕ(x∗)Tw¯,ϕ(x∗)TA−1ϕ(x∗)),

    where w¯=1σn2A−1Φ(X)Ty and A=1σn2Φ(X)TΦ(X)+Σp−1.

  • We can rewrite the eq. (2.11) in the following way

    (2.12)p(f∗|x∗,X,y)=N(f∗|(ϕ∗TΣpΦT)(K+σn2I)−1y,(ϕ∗TΣpϕ∗)−(ϕ∗TΣpΦT)(K+σn2I)−1(ΦΣpϕ∗)),

    where ϕ∗=ϕ(x∗), Φ=Φ(X), and K=ΦΣpΦT.

    (∵) For the mean, 1σn2ΦT(K+σn2I)=AΣpΦT implies 1σn2A−1ΦT=ΣpΦT(K+σn2I)−1.

    For the variance, we use the matrix inversion lemma:

    (Z+UWVT)−1=Z−1−Z−1U(W−1+VTZ−1U)−1VTZ−1,

    where Z−1=Σp, W−1=σn2I, and U=V=ΦT.

  • In particular, when N<D¯, it is more convenient to invert the N×N matrix K+σ2IN than to invert the D¯×D¯ matrix A.

     

Define k(x,x′)≡ϕ(x)TΣpϕ(x′) called a covariance function or kernel.

  • k(x,x′) is an inner product (w.r.t. Σp).

    Since Σp is positive definite, we can define Σp1/2 so that (Σp1/2)2=Σp. Then k(x,x′)=ψ(x)⋅ψ(x′), where ψ(x)=Σp1/2ϕ(x).

  • (kernel trick) If an algorithm is defined solely in terms of inner products in input space, then it can be lifted into feature space by replacing occurrences of those inner products by k(x,x′).

 

 

2.2 Function-space View

Think of a Gaussian processes as defining a distribution over functions, and inference taking place directly in the space of functions.

 

Definition 2.1 A Gaussian process is a collection of random variables, any finite number of which have a joint Gaussian distribution (or a multivariate normal distribution).

  • A Gaussian process f(x) is completely specified by its mean function and covariance function:

    m(x)≡E[f(x)],k(x,x′)≡E[(f(x)−m(x))(f(x′)−m(x′))],

    and we will write the Gaussian process as

    f(x)∼GP(m(x),k(x,x′)).

  • In our case the random variables represent the function value f(x).

  • (Bayesian linear regression model) For simple example of a Gaussian process, if f(x)=ϕ(x)Tw with prior w∼N(0,Σp), then the mean and covariance functions are

    m(x)≡E[f(x)]=ϕ(x)TE[w]=0,k(x,x′)≡E[f(x)f(x′)]=E[(ϕ(x)Tw)(wTϕ(x′))]=ϕ(x)TE[wwT]ϕ(x′)=ϕ(x)TΣpϕ(x′).

 

Marginalization Property (claude.ai)

For a joint distribution over a finite number of random variables, the marginal distribution always exists.

  • This is a fundamental property of probability theory: If you have a joint distribution over (X1,X2,…,Xn), you can always marginalize to get the distribution of any subset of variables.

However, the situation becomes more complex when dealing with infinite-dimensional objects, like stochastic processes. In these cases:

  1. The existence of well-defined marginal distributions for arbitrary subsets is not guaranteed without certain consistency conditions.

  2. These consistency conditions are precisely what's addressed by the Kolmogorov Extension Theorem, which provides criteria for when a collection of finite-dimensional distributions can be extended to a proper stochastic process.

  3. For Gaussian processes specifically, the properties of the mean and covariance functions ensure that these consistency conditions are automatically satisfied, which is why GPs are mathematically well-behaved despite being infinite-dimensional.

    (GP의 경우 어떤 유한 개의 점 {xn∣1≤n≤N}을 선택하더라도 covariance 함수 k(x,x′)으로부터 생성되는 N×N 행렬 K (즉 Ki,j=k(xi,xj))는 GP의 정의로부터 가우시안 분포의 covariance 행렬이 되어야만 한다.)

    The remarkable aspect of Gaussian processes is that they provide a tractable way to work with infinite-dimensional distributions through their finite-dimensional marginals, which are always guaranteed to exist and maintain consistency with each other.

 

Sampling Function Values using Squared Exponential (SE)

Suppose the mean function m(x)=0 and the covariance function is given by the squared exponential (SE) or radian basis function (RBF),

k(xp,xq)=exp⁡(−|xp−xq|22l2)∈(0,1],

where the characteristic length-scale l=1.

  • Gaussian process regression can be viewed as Bayesian linear regression with a possibly infinite number of basis functions ϕ(x). One possible basis set is the eigenfunctions of the covariance function. (See §4.3.)

  • The specification of the covariance function implies a distribution over functions: Sample function values f∗ from the prior distribution N(0,K(X∗,X∗)).

    1. Choose a set of test points X∗.

      X_test = np.linspace(start=-5, stop=5, num=50)[:,np.newaxis]

    2. Write out the corresponding covariance matrix K(X∗,X∗) using SE.

      xxxxxxxxxx
      from sklearn.gaussian_process.kernels import RBF
      kernel = RBF(length_scale=1.0, length_scale_bounds="fixed")
      K_test = kernel(X_test, X_test)

    3. Generate random (multivariate) Gaussian vectors f∗∼N(0,K(X∗,X∗)).

      xxxxxxxxxx
      rng = np.random.default_rng(seed=18)
      f_test = rng.multivariate_normal(mean=np.zeros(50), cov=K_test, size=3) # of shape (3, 50)

    4. Plot the generated function values f∗ as a function of the inputs. (Figure 2.2(a))

      xxxxxxxxxx
      ax.fill_between(
          X_test.squeeze(), -1.96, 1.96,
          color="gray", alpha=0.25, label="95% confidence interval"
      )
      for f in f_test:
          ax.plot(X_test, f, linewidth=0.5)
          ax.scatter(X_test, f, s=5)

 

Prediction with Noise-free Observations

We are usually not primarily interested in drawing random functions from the prior, but want to incorporate the knowledge that the training data provides about the function.

We will consider the simple special case where the observations are noise free, that is we know {(xn,fn)∣n=1,…,N}, where fn=f(xn).

Let X be training points and let X∗ be test points.

  • In this example, we choose the (true) function values fn for training points randomly from N(0,1).

    xxxxxxxxxx
    rng = np.random.default_rng(seed=5)
    train_indices = rng.choice(np.arange(50), size=5, replace=False)
    X_train = X_test[train_indices]
    y_train = rng.normal(size=5)

The joint distribution of the training outputs f=f(X) and the test outputs f∗=f(X∗) according to the prior is

[ff∗]∼N(0,[K(X,X)K(X,X∗)K(X∗,X)K(X∗,X∗)]).

The posterior distribution over functions is

(2.9)p(f∗|X,X∗,f)=N(K(X∗,X)K(X,X)−1f,K(X∗,X∗)−K(X∗,X)K(X,X)−1K(X,X∗)).

Reference: Probabilistic Machine Learning: An Introduction, 3.2.3 Marginals and conditionals of an MVN (p.82)

  • Function values f∗ can be sampled from the joint posterior distribution (2.9).

    xxxxxxxxxx
    from sklearn.gaussian_process import GaussianProcessRegressor
    gaussian_process = GaussianProcessRegressor(kernel).fit(X_train, y_train)
    mean_pred, std_pred = gaussian_process.predict(X_test, return_std=True)
    f_sample = gaussian_process.sample_y(X_test, n_samples=3) # of shape (50, 3)

  • Figure 2.2(b) shows the sampled function values f∗ given the 5 training points X marked with + symbols.

    xxxxxxxxxx
    ax.fill_between(
        X_test.squeeze(), mean_pred - 1.96 * std_pred, mean_pred + 1.96 * std_pred,
        color="gray", alpha=0.25, label="95% confidence interval"
    )
    for f in f_sample.T:
        ax.plot(X_test, f, linewidth=0.5)
        ax.scatter(X_test, f, s=5)
    ax.plot(X_test, mean_pred, label="Mean prediction", color="tab:red")
    ax.scatter(
        X_train, y_train, s=100, marker="+", label="Observations", color="tab:red"
    )

 

Prediction using Noisy Observations

It is typical for more realistic modeling situations that y=f(x)+ϵ, where ϵ∼N(0,σn2). Then the prior on the noisy observations becomes

cov(yp,yq)=k(xp,xq)+σn2δpqorcov(y)=K(X,X)+σn2I

We can write the joint distribution of the observed target values and the function values at the test points X∗ under the prior as

[yf∗]∼N(0,[K(X,X)+σn2IK(X,X∗)K(X∗,X)K(X∗,X∗)]).

  • (Key predictive equations for Gaussian process regression)

    (2.22)p(f∗|X,X∗,y)=N(f∗|f¯∗,cov(f∗)),

    where

    (2.23)f¯∗=K(X∗,X)[K(X,X)+σn2I]−1y,(2.24)cov(f∗)=K(X∗,X∗)−K(X∗,X)[K(X,X)+σn2I]−1K(X,X∗).
    xxxxxxxxxx
    sigma_n = 0.2
    y_train_noisy = y_train + rng.normal(loc=0, scale=sigma_n, size=y_train.shape)
    gaussian_process = GaussianProcessRegressor(kernel, alpha=sigma_n**2)
    gaussian_process.fit(X_train, y_train_noisy)
    mean_pred, std_pred = gaussian_process.predict(X_test, return_std=True)
    f_sample = gaussian_process.sample_y(X_test, n_samples=3) # of shape (50, 3)
    xxxxxxxxxx
    ax.fill_between(
        X_test.squeeze(), mean_pred - 1.96 * std_pred, mean_pred + 1.96 * std_pred,
        color="gray", alpha=0.25, label="95% confidence interval"
    )
    for f in f_sample.T:
        ax.plot(X_test, f, linewidth=0.5)
        ax.scatter(X_test, f, s=5)
    ax.plot(X_test, mean_pred, label="Mean prediction", color="tab:red")
    ax.errorbar(
        X_train, y_train_noisy, sigma_n, label="Observations",
        linestyle="None", color="tab:red", marker="+", markersize=10
    )

  • We have exact correspondence with the weight space view in (2.12) when identifying

    K(x∗,X)=ϕ(x∗)TΣpΦ(X)TK(X,x∗)=Φ(X)Σpϕ(x∗)=K(x∗,X)TK(X,X)=Φ(X)ΣpΦ(X)Tk(x∗,x∗)=ϕ(x∗)TΣpϕ(x∗).

  • For any set of basis functions ϕ(xp), we can compute the corresponding covariance function as k(xp,xq)=ϕ(xp)TΣpϕ(xq); conversely, for every (positive definite) covariance function k, there exists a (possibly infinite) expansion in terms of basis functions. (See Mercer's Theorem in §4.3.)

  • In the case of one test point X∗={x∗}, if we write k∗≡K(X,x∗) and K=K(X,X), then (2.23) and (2.24) reduce to

    (2.25)f¯∗=k∗T(K+σn2I)−1y,(2.26)V[f∗]=k(x∗,x∗)−k∗T(K+σn2I)−1k∗.

  • (Linear predictor) The mean prediction (2.25) is a linear combination of observations y.

    Another way to look (2.25) is to see it as a linear combination of N kernel functions, each one centered on a training point,

    f¯(x∗)=∑n=1Nαnk(xn,x∗),

    where α=(α1,…,αN)=(K+σn2I)−1y.

  • The variance cov(f∗) in (2.24) or V[f∗] in (2.26) does not depend on the observed targets y, but only on the inputs X; this is a property of the Gaussian distribution.

  • The marginal likelihood (or evidence) p(y|X) is the integral of the likelihood times the prior

    p(y|X)=∫p(y|X,f)p(f|X)df.

    The term marginal likelihood refers to the marginalization over the function values f. (Prior 분포에서 샘플되는 (훈련셋 X 위의) 모든 함숫값 f에 대한 (노이즈가 들어간) 관찰값 y의 가능도의 기댓값)

  • Under the Gaussian process model, the prior is Gaussian f|X∼N(f|0,K) and the likelihood is a factorized Gaussian y|f∼N(y|f,σn2I) so that

    p(y|X)=∫N(y|f,σn2I)N(f|0,K)df=N(y|0,K+σn2I).

    Reference: Probabilistic Machine Learning: An Introduction, 3.3.1 Bayes rule for Gaussians (p.85)

  • The log marginal likelihood is

    (2.30)log⁡p(y|X)=−12yT(K+σn2I)−1y−12log⁡|K+σn2I|−N2log⁡2π.
    xxxxxxxxxx
    gaussian_process = GaussianProcessRegressor(kernel).fit(X_train, y_train)
    gaussian_process.log_marginal_likelihood() # of y_train over X_train

    (scikit-learn의 GaussianProcessRegressor는 훈련셋 (X_train,y_train)에 대한 log⁡p(y|X)가 최대가 되도록 커널의 하이퍼파라미터를 조정한다. Chapter 5 참조)

 

Practical Implementation of Gaussian Process Regression

The Cholesky decomposition of a symmetric positive definite matrix A decomposes A into a product of a lower triangular matrix L and its transpose LLT=A, where L is called the Cholesky factor.

  • To solve Ax=b for x, solve (1) the triangular system Ly=b by forward substitution and then (2) the triangular system LTx=y by back substitution.

  • Using the backslash operator, we write the solution as x=LT∖(L∖b), where the notation A∖b is the vector x which solves Ax=b.

  • Note also that the determinant of a positive definite symmetric matrix can be calculated efficiently by |A|=∏iLii2, where L is the Cholesky factor from A.

A practical implementation of Gaussian process regression (GPR) is shown in Algorithm 2.1.

  • Predictive mean: LLT=K+σn2I (line 2) and α=(K+σn2I)−1y (line 3)

  • Predictive variance: If K+σn2I is invertible, so is L. Thus k∗=Lv (line 5) implies k∗T(K+σ2IN)−1k∗=(Lv)T(LLT)−1(Lv)=vTv.

 

scikit-learn API of Gaussian Process Regression

Reference: GaussianProcessRegressor. https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.gaussian_process.GaussianProcessRegressor.html

xxxxxxxxxx
class sklearn.gaussian_process.GaussianProcessRegressor(
    kernel=None, *,
    alpha=1e-10, optimizer='fmin_l_bfgs_b', n_restarts_optimizer=0,
    normalize_y=False, copy_X_train=True, n_targets=None, random_state=None
)

Parameters:

  • kernel: The kernel specifying the covariance function of the GP. If None is passed, the kernel ConstantKernel(1.0, constant_value_bounds="fixed") * RBF(length_scale=1.0, length_scale_bounds="fixed") is used as default.

  • alpha: (1) Value added to the diagonal of the kernel matrix during fitting. This can prevent a potential numerical issue during fitting, by ensuring that the calculated values form a positive definite matrix. (2) It can also be interpreted as the variance σ2 of additional Gaussian measurement noise on the training observations. (alpha에 하나의 float 값 대신 ndarray를 입력하면, 훈련셋의 각 점에 서로 다른 노이즈를 줄 수 있다.)

    ​x
    # scikit-learn/sklearn/gaussian_process/_gpr.py
    

    340  # Precompute quantities required for predictions which are independent
    341  # of actual query points
    342  # Alg. 2.1, page 19, line 2 -> L = cholesky(K + sigma^2 I)
    343  K = self.kernel_(self.X_train_)
    344  K[np.diag_indices_from(K)] += self.alpha

Attributes:

  • kernel_: The kernel k (covariance function) used for prediction. The structure of the kernel is the same as the one passed as parameter but with optimized hyperparameters.

  • L_: Lower-triangular Cholesky decomposition L (line #2 in Algorithm 2.1) of the kernel in X_train_.

  • alpha_: Dual coefficients α (line 3 in Algorithm 2.1) of training data points in kernel space.

Methods:

  • fit(X, y): Fit Gaussian process regression model.

  • predict(X_test, return_std=False, return_cov=False): Predict using the Gaussian process regression model. We can also predict based on an unfitted model by using the GP prior.

    In addition to the mean of the predictive distribution, optionally also returns its standard deviation (return_std=True) or covariance (return_cov=True). Note that at most one of the two can be requested. (Using Algorithm 2.1)

  • sample_y(X_test, n_samples=1, random_state=0): Draw samples from Gaussian process and evaluate at X_test.

  • score(X_test, y_test, sample_weight=None): Return the coefficient of determination R2 of the prediction.

  • log_marginal_likelihood(theta=None, eval_gradient=False, clone_kernel=True): Return log-marginal likelihood of theta (the non-fixed, log-transformed hyperparameters of the kernel) for training data y_train_. (line 7 in Algorithm 2.1)

 

 

2.3 Varying the Hyperparameters

In this section our aim is more simply to explore the effects of varying the hyperparameters on GP prediction.

For example, consider the SE covariance function in one dimension,

ky(xp,xq)=σf2exp⁡(−(xp−xq)22l2)+σn2δpq,

where hyperparameters are the length-scale l, the signal variance σf2, and the noise variance σn.

xxxxxxxxxx
from sklearn.gaussian_process.kernels import RBF, WhiteKernel
kernel = sigma_f**2 * RBF(length_scale=l, length_scale_bounds=(1e-5, 10^5)) + \
         sigma_n**2 * WhiteKernel(noise_level=1, noise_level_bounds=(1e-5, 10^5))

  • Figure 2.5(a) shows the 2σ error bars (95% confidence region) for the predictions obtained using the hyperparameters (l,σf,σn)=(1,1,0.1) as eq. (2.9).

    Notice how the error bars get larger for input values that are distant from any training points.

  • If we make predictions with a process with l=0.3 on the data generated from the l=1 process then we obtain the result in Figure 2.5(b).

    The remaining two parameters were set by optimizing the marginal likelihood p(y|X). (Chapter 5. Model Selection and Adaptation of Hyperparameters)

    In this case, σn=0.00005 (overfitting) as the greater flexibility of the signal means that the noise level can be reduced.

    Notice also that the short length-scale means that the error bars in Figure 2.5(b) grow rapidly away from the datapoints.

  • In contrast, we can set l=3 as shown in Figure 2.5(c). Again the remaining two parameters were set by optimizing the marginal likelihood.

    In the case σn=0.89 (underfitting) and we see that the data is now explained by a slowly varying function with a lot of noise.

 

 

2.4 Decision Theory for Regression

The predictive distribution of y∗ corresponding to the test input x∗ is Gaussian with mean and variance given by eq. (2.25) and (2.26).

p(y∗|x∗,D)=N(y∗|k∗T(K+σn2I)−1y,k(x∗,x∗)−k∗T(K+σn2I)−1k∗)

In practical applications, however, we need a point-like prediction, a loss function L(ytrue,yguess), which is optimal in some sense.

  • We computed the predictive distribution without reference to the loss function.

  • In non-Bayesian setting, the model is typically trained by minimizing the empirical risk (or loss).

  • In the Bayesian setting, there is a clear separation between the likelihood function (used for training, in addition to the prior) and the loss function.

    1. The likelihood function describes how the noisy measurements are assumed to deviate from the underlying noise-free function.

    2. The loss function captures the consequences of making a specific choice, given an actual true state.

Our goal is to make the point prediction yguess which incurs the smallest loss, but how can we achieve that when we don't know ytrue?

  • We minimize the expected loss (or risk),

    R~L(yguess|x∗)=∫L(y∗,yguess)p(y∗|x∗,D)dy∗.

  • Our best guess is

    yoptimal|x∗=arg⁡minyguessR~L(yguess|x∗).

    • In general, (1) yoptimal is the median of p(y∗|x∗,D) for the loss L=|yguess−y∗|, (2) while for the loss L=(yguess−y∗)2, it is the mean of p(y∗|x∗,D).

      (∵) P(y≤yguess)=P(y>yguess)=0.5, since

      0=ddyguessR~L(y|x)=∫−∞yguess(−1)p(y)dy+∫yguess∞(+1)p(y)dy=−P(y≤yguess)+P(y>yguess).

    • When the predictive distribution is Gaussian, the mean and the median coincide.

    • Indeed, for any symmetric loss function and symmetric predictive distribution we always get yguess as the mean of the predictive distribution.

    • However, in many practical problems the loss functions can be asymmetric.

 

 

2.5 An Example Application

References:

  1. The SARCOS data. https://gaussianprocess.org/gpml/data/

  2. SARCOS Problem. https://github.com/JohDonald/SARCOS-problem

 

We use Gaussian process regression to learn the inverse dynamics of a seven degrees-of-freedom SARCOS anthropomorphic robot arm.

[claude.ai] The SARCOS anthropomorphic robot arm is a robotic arm system that has become a benchmark dataset in machine learning, particularly for evaluating regression and inverse dynamics models.

Key features of the SARCOS robot arm:

  1. Design: It's a 7 degrees-of-freedom (DOF) robotic arm designed to mimic human arm movements, hence "anthropomorphic" (사람의 모습을 닮은)

  2. Dataset: The associated SARCOS dataset contains:

  • Input features: 21 values (7 joint angular positions (in radians), 7 joint angular velocities, and 7 joint angular accelerations)

  • Output targets: 7 joint torques required to achieve the specified motion

    • Dataset size: 44,484 training set and 4,449 test set

    • Standard normalization: Both input and output variables are normalized to have zero mean and unit variance on the training set

  1. Research applications: The dataset is widely used for:

    • Learning complex non-linear relationships

    • Testing machine learning algorithms for robot control

    • Evaluating how well methods can model the inverse dynamics problem (predicting required torques from desired movements)

  2. Benchmark: It's become a standard benchmark for comparing the performance of various machine learning methods, especially Gaussian processes, neural networks, and other regression techniques.

The dataset gained prominence in the machine learning community after being used in influential papers on Gaussian process regression and has since been referenced in numerous studies on robotic control and machine learning.

 

Given a prediction method, we can evaluate the quality of predictions in several ways.

Standardized Mean Squared Error (SMSE)

  • SMSE=MSEVar(y) where MSE=1N∑n(yn−f(xn))2 and Var(y) is the variance of the true target values in the test set.

  • Scale invariance: It normalizes the prediction error by the inherent variability in the data, making it more comparable across different output dimensions or datasets.

  • Interpretation: It can be interpreted as the proportion of variance in the target that remains unexplained by the model.

    • SMSE=0 means perfect prediction. (f(xn)=yn for all n)

    • SMSE=1 means the model performs no better than simply predicting the mean of the target. (f(xn)=y¯ for all n)

    • SMSE>1 indicate the model performs worse than predicting the mean.

  • This metric is particularly useful when working with multiple output dimensions that have different scales or when comparing performance across different datasets.

 

If we produce a predictive distribution at each test input we can evaluate the negative log probability of the target under the model.

−log⁡p(y∗|x∗,D)=12log⁡(2πσ∗2)+(y∗−f(x∗))22σ∗2,

where the predictive variance σ∗2=Var[f∗]+σ2 for GPR and Var[f∗] is given by eq. (2.26).

Mean Standardized Log Loss (MSLL)

The log loss can be standardized by subtracting the loss that would be obtained under the trivial model which predicts using a Gaussian with mean and variance of the training data.

SLL=Log Loss−Log Losstrivial=−log⁡p(y∗|x∗,D)+log⁡N(y∗|y¯train,σtrain2),

where y¯train and σtrain2 is the mean and the variance of the true target values in the training set, respectively.

The mean SLL is denoted MSLL. It measures the information gain relative to the trivial model. The interpretation becomes:

  • MSLL=0: The model performs equivalently to the trivial model (predicting the overall mean and variance).

  • MSLL<0: The model outperforms the trivial model (provides information gain).

  • MSLL>0: The model performs worse than the trivial model.

 

  • The rigid-body-dynamics (RBD) model has a number of free parameters; these were estimated by Vijayakumar et al. [2005] using a least-squares fitting procedure.

  • The locally weighted projection regression (LWPR) method of Vijayakumar et al. [2005] is an on-line method that cycles through the dataset multiple times.

 

 

2.6 Smoothing, Weight Functions and Equivalent Kernels

Linear smoother

Gaussian process regression aims to reconstruct the underlying signal f by removing the contaminating noise ϵ.

To do this it computes a weighted average of the noisy observations y as f¯(x∗)=k∗T(K+σ2IN)−1y in eq. (2.25), where k∗=K(X,x∗).

Since f¯(x∗) is a linear combination of the y values, Gaussian process regression is a linear smoother.

  • Linear model: The prediction is a linear combination of the inputs.

  • Linear smoother: The prediction is a linear combination of the target values in the training set.

 

Weight functions (discrete)

The weight function describes how an observation at a given point influences the prediction at another point. It essentially represents the influence of training data on the GP posterior (predictive) mean

f¯(x∗)=k∗T(K+σ2IN)−1y=∑n=1Nwn(x∗)yn,

where wn(x∗)=[(K+σ2IN)−1k∗]n.

  • The weight function determines how much each training point yn contributes to the prediction at x∗.

  • Understanding the form (shape) of the weight function is made complicated by (K+σ2IN)−1 and the fact that K depends on the specific locations of the N datapoints.

  • Idealizing the situation one can consider the observations to be smeared out (번지다) in x-space at some density of observations. (discrete to continuous)

 

Equivalent kernels (continuous)

The equivalent kernel (or smoothing kernel) describes the behavior of a GP in terms of classical kernel regression (such as Nadaraya-Watson kernel smoothing). It represents the continuous kernel that would produce similar discrete smoothing (of the weight function) in the limit of infinite training data.

In the limit of large data, the GP posterior (predictive) mean can be written as

f¯(x∗)=∫h(x∗,x′)y(x′)dx′,

where h(x∗,x′) is the equivalent kernel (or smoothing kernel), which acts as an effective weighting function for continuous function estimation.

  • A standard form of the equivalent kernel for a GP is

    h(x∗,x′)=k(x∗,x′)−k∗T(K+σ2IN)−1K(X,x′).

  • The key insight is that the weight function wn(x∗) represents the "sampling" of the equivalent kernel at the discrete training locations.

  • The equivalent kernel gives the continuous generalization of how influence varies across the entire input space, while the weight function shows the specific weights applied to the actual training data points.

 

The predicted mean values f¯ at the training points X are given by

(2.35)f¯=K(X,X)[K(X,X)+σ2IN]−1y.

  • Let K=K(X,X) have the eigendecomposition K=∑nλnununT, where λn is the n-th eigenvalue and un is the corresponding eigenvector.

  • As K is real and symmetric positive semidefinite, λn's are real and non-negative, and un's are mutually orthogonal.

  • Let y=∑nγnun for some γn=unTy. Then

    (2.36)f¯=∑nγnλnλn+σ2un.

    (∵) K+σ2IN=∑nλnununT+σ2∑nununT and its inverse is ∑n1λn+σ2ununT.

  • Notice that if λnλn+σ2≪1 then the component in y along un is effectively eliminated.

    For most covariance functions that are used in practice the eigenvalues are larger for more slowly varying eigenvectors (e.g. fewer zero-crossings) so that this means that high-frequency components in y are smoothed out.

  • The effective number of parameters or degrees of freedom of the smoother is defined as

    traceK(K+σ2IN)−1=∑nλnλn+σ2.

    This counts the number of eigenvectors which are not eliminated.
